text:
Crime and Punishment

“Should he give it to me? I know he won’t, but I still go to him.”

“Why do you go?” Raskolnikov asked.

“Well, when you have no one and nowhere else to go, you have to go somewhere. Everyone needs a place to go, especially when it’s really important. When my daughter first went out with a yellow ticket, I had to go… (because my daughter has a yellow passport),” he added quickly, looking a bit nervous at the young man. “It doesn’t matter, sir, it doesn’t matter!” he continued quickly, trying to stay calm as both boys at the counter laughed and even the innkeeper smiled. “It doesn’t matter; I’m not bothered by their jokes because everyone knows everything already, and all secrets are out in the open. I accept it all, not with hate, but with humility. So be it! So be it! ‘Look at the man!’ Excuse me, young man, can you… No, let me say it more clearly; not can you, but do you dare to say that I am not a pig?”

The young man didn’t say anything.

“Well,” the speaker began again, with even more dignity after the laughter died down. “Well, I am a pig, but she is a lady! I may look like a beast, but Katerina Ivanovna, my wife, is educated and the daughter of an officer. Sure, I’m a scoundrel, but she has a noble heart, full of feelings, and refined by education. And yet… oh, if only she cared for me! Honored sir, every man should have at least one place where…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The speaker laments his low status and contrasts himself with his noble wife, expressing a deep desire for her affection and understanding.
